div.ab: and its shadow must spread everywhere.

35. Likewise, to depict Vulcan, Cyclops,
with their bare limbs, who made
the mountain Gibelli tremble with their blows,
forging there the thunderbolt of Jupiter,
place one [figure] among the company
against the light, fully in shadow, and
paint the firelight, as is fitting,
striking its outline here and there as it faces us.

37. When the light is in its proper place, take care
where the reflection should overwhelm the shadow.
But speaking of lights and night,
in the Vatican in Rome the powers appear
in a scene where Peter lies deeply asleep
between two Soldiers, on whose weapons [appears]
the reflection of the angel in the dungeon,
proving well what manner of painter Raphael was.
right-middleExample of a night scene, with various lights, painted by Raphael.

38. One also sees Peter leaving with the Angel,
where a Sentinel holds a Torch,
which wakes up a second guard outside,
and the reflection from this torch’s fire,
and elsewhere, the moonlight
strike places on the armor itself. Further, the daylight
passing through a window is considered with intelligence
since it gives these lights a natural appearance.
right-middleThis piece is in Fresco in the Papal palace; read of it in Raphael’s Life.

39. Among all who work on night scenes
from colors in Pictures,
with brilliant reflecting lights,
the elder Bassano could fool the eye
naturally with great excellence.
For one seems to see clearly before one’s eyes
Flames, Torches, hanging lamps,
and Pots and Kettles which receive reflection.
right-middleThe elder Bassano was outstanding at painting night scenes, and skilled at reflection.

40. Utensils of Copper, Tin, and Iron,
fleecy Sheep, and all kinds of Animals,
The Annunciation to the Shepherds, The Flight into Egypt,
Various nocturnes, witty gestures
Of Figures giving elegance to the work;
